Award.AbstractNarration: This award is for an international meeting "The 7th Xanthomonas Genomics Conference", which will be held in Clearwater, Florida and organized by faculty at the University of Florida and Auburn University. The Conference centers on two diverse groups of plant associated and plant pathogenic bacteria (i.e., Xanthomonas and Xylella) that negatively impact the environment and impact crop production both in yield and quality of plant species important for food, fiber, and energy. Further, the conference provides support for early career professionals and graduate students to attend and incorporates opportunities for interactions with participants who are underrepresented in STEM disciplines.<br/><br/>Xanthomonas and the closely related Xylella constitute the largest and arguably the most important groups of plant pathogenic bacteria. In addition to their importance in agriculture and as models for understanding plant bacterial interactions, Xanthomonas spp. are also important in the development of transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALEN), a genome editing tool commonly used for crop improvement. The 7th Xanthomonas Genomics Conference (7XGC) will provide a venue for Xanthomonas/Xylella researchers and others to share recent results and ideas that deepen our understanding of the fundamental processes that mediate plant-pathogen interactions and develop improved disease control strategies. The broader impacts of the conference are the following: (1) The conference will provide a venue to share and discuss recent discoveries; (2) identify important challenges and opportunities; (3) present new technologies and approaches; (4) train next generation scientists; (5) promote international collaboration; and (6) determine key resources for continued, community-driven advances.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits. The NSF grant was used to support the 7th Xanthomonas Genomics Conference (7XGC) held in Clearwater, Florida on June 13-17, 2022.  The 7XGC was originally scheduled to take place between 05/07/2021 and 05/03/2022. Due to COVID19, it was postponed to June 13-17, 2022.  The 7XGC was organized by faculty at the University of Florida and Auburn University. This conference focused on Xanthomonas and the closely related Xylella which constitute the largest and arguably the most important groups of plant pathogenic bacteria. Members cause diseases on almost all plant hosts, including many crop and ornamental species, as well as model species such as Arabidopsis thaliana, rice, tomato, and Medicago truncatula (Wang et al., 1996; Buell and Somerville, 1997; Schwartz et al., 2015; Terrasson et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2019). In addition to their importance in agriculture and as models for understanding plant bacterial interactions, Xanthomonas spp. are also important in the development of transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALEN), a genome editing tool commonly used for crop improvement such as generating disease resistant varieties (Li et al., 2012). The 7XGC provided a venue for over 100 Xanthomonas/Xylella researchers and others to share recent results and ideas that deepen our understanding of the fundamental processes that mediate plant-pathogen interactions.  The 7XGC convened scientists from around the world who are engaged in research aimed at 1) increasing our understanding of bacterial adaptation to the extraordinary diversity of plant hosts and host tissues, and 2) developing improved control strategies for reducing diseases caused by Xanthomonas spp. and Xylella.  

Broader Impacts. The broader impacts of the conference are the following:

(1) The conference provided a venue to share and discuss recent discoveries.  

The 7XGC included 41 oral presentations and 31 poster presentations. Those presentations covered a broad range of topics on Xanthomonas and Xylella including genomics, plant immunity, secretion systems and effectors and other virulence factors, biotechnology, diagnostics, epidemiology, and disease control.

(2) identified important challenges and opportunities.

During the presentations and round table discussion, we identified important challenges regarding how to use the genome editing tools to generate disease resistant varieties, how to control different diseases, how to prevent pathogens from overcoming plant resistance. We have talked about the opportunities present to the community in term of genome editing, TALEN, and next generation sequencing.

(3) presented new technologies and approaches.

Among the 41 oral presentations and 31 poster presentations, new technologies and approaches were presented including TELEN, CRISPR genome editing, GWAS, metagenomic sequencing for diagnosis, artificial intelligence.

(4) trained next generation scientists.

The 7XGC provided travel support ($500 for domestic and $1000 for international) to 10 students and 6 early career scientists (e.g., postdocs and equivalents). Among the attendees, 39 are students and 19 are early career scientists.

(5) promoted international collaboration.

Among the attendees, 52 are domestic and 47 are international from 13 countries. The 7XGC provided an opportunity for international collaboration.

(6) determined key resources for continued, community-driven advances.

During the round table discussion, we have discussed key resources for continued, community-driven advances.

Overall, the 7XGC has significantly promoted sharing of recent discoveries, new technologies, identified challenges and opportunities, supported and trained next generation scientists, and promoted international collaboration.
